projects.title: read.my.column
projects.context: Computation Arts Course: CART351 - Network & Navigation
projects.abstract: read.my.column is a WebGL navigable prototype. It hopes to critique how newspaper headlines are often over sensationalistic and diverge from their primary informational purpose. read.my.column brings to awareness click bates in the informative online medias and further pushes the disconnected between headline and content by means of generative poetry and typography.

content.text: The origin

The motivation for this project comes from my personal struggles to find reliable, but also pragmatic source of information. The hyper-sensationalistic tone of headlines would often repel me from consuming news.

I validated my perception by visiting numerous mainstream news media. While some were better than others, I still found clickbait headlines with content less scandalous than advertised. I suspect Web analytics to have a role in this because an online newspapers' success is measured yes in terms of subscription, but more importantly in terms of clicks.

I did not focus on the issue of 'fake news', but it is inherent to my subject. Headlines, for fake news artists, are the best weapon. They frame the rest of the experience, but can affect what existing knowledge is activated in our heads and influence our mindset to recall details that coincide with expectation.”[1] Thus, a misleading headline would have an impact not only prior reading the article (if read at all), but also after, as it is remembered and maybe shared with others.
Why call it "read.my.column"?

This digital experience seeks to share my opinion on the subject and I thought this title best both for its reference to the recurrent publications of one's opinion - the column,- but also because it inspired the shapes my visual poetry.
visual representation of the "columns"
Why poetry?
Because it bears more intensity with its artistic and expressionistic qualities and had the potential to reflect the intensity of emotion-triggering headlines.

Defining the interaction

The experience is meant to present itself as a forest of columns growing each day from the latest news. Each column is composed of a single headline positioned in a helicoidal string rotating on its central axis.
Counter-clockwise storyboard
sketch // storyboard

text: 1. User enter the 3D space and navigate using AWSD keys and mouse. Text columns are at a reasonable distance from one another to minimize the overlap, maximize readability, and ensure a one-at-a-time experience.
2. On click, show the poem. The poem is generated once when columns are added daily. It is the same for all users.
2.1 Button interaction → Users may compose a line and contribute to the poem.
2.2 Button interaction → Users may show their appreciation.
2.3 Button interaction → Users may share a comment on current column content.
3. Additional lines will show up as roots below the column.
4. And additional lines will be permanently added to the poem for all to read and edit.
5. Columns that have been interacted with (clicks, comments, lines, appreciations) will grow larger and higher. Those with no interaction will slowly decay and leave space for newer columns.

content.text: The right tool for the right job

text.why: Unusual, dynamic, and memorable text treatment.
Sense of infinite space, freedom of movement, and highly interactive with camera and arrow-key navigation built-in.
Allows for unexpected poetry, either very good or pretty bad.
Locate articles and breaking news headlines from news sources and blogs across the web.
Bypass subscription requirements to get more words and data into the poem generator program.

text.body: Get the full article through HTML tags, like "p" or "article".
The article's body is deconstructed into parts of speech and reconstructed placing words according to poem templates.
Add the generated poem, the article URL, and its healdine to a database.
Append headlines as interactive columns rotating.
Manage user interactions (navigation, clicks, comments, likes, etc.) and store into database.

content.text:
The development was divided into two sections:
  • NewsAPI, PHP Webscrapping & RiTa.js
  • Three.js & User interactions
The database was the last intended step: the bridge connecting the two independent programs into one seemless experience.
